content.raw:
An alternative to all of this is setting a very high MCVR/MCSR value to prevent vanishing/splitting altogether; however, as per Prof Bilmes on segway-internal:

"Note that you actually *can* adjust the mcvr and mcsr so that vanishing never happens, I wouldn't advise turning it off completely since in that case you could get components with essentially zero responsibility (which will mean you'll be doing more redundant computation consisting of multiplying possibly numerically less stable computations (e.g., small variance Gaussians) by zero, and adding zeros). If you do the Dirichlet constant stuff I sent in the previous email, you can safely do vanishing with Dirichlet priors."
content.html:
An alternative to all of this is setting a very high MCVR/MCSR value to prevent vanishing/splitting altogether; however, as per Prof Bilmes on segway-internal:

"Note that you actually can adjust the mcvr and mcsr so that vanishing never happens, I wouldn't advise turning it off completely since in that case you could get components with essentially zero responsibility (which will mean you'll be doing more redundant computation consisting of multiplying possibly numerically less stable computations (e.g., small variance Gaussians) by zero, and adding zeros). If you do the Dirichlet constant stuff I sent in the previous email, you can safely do vanishing with Dirichlet priors."

content.raw: Presumably MCVR and MCSR stands for "Mixture Component Vanishing Ratio" and "Mixture Component Splitting Ratio" correct?
content.html: Presumably MCVR and MCSR stands for "Mixture Component Vanishing Ratio" and "Mixture Component Splitting Ratio" correct?

content.raw: Yes and no; it's a ratio, not a rate. Please see pg 578 of the GMTK documentation
content.html: Yes and no; it's a ratio, not a rate. Please see pg 578 of the GMTK documentation

content.raw: Thanks! Updated.
content.html: Thanks! Updated.

content.raw: What is `cl0` and `cl1`? And why the change from `cl0` to `cl1`? Please use `diff -u` in the future.
content.html: What is cl0 and cl1? And why the change from cl0 to cl1? Please use diff -u in the future.

content.raw:
I think the `_cl` suffix indicates a 'clone (at least per the GMTK source code; line 233 of `GMTK_MeanVector.cc`). My guess is that one or more Gaussians have split and that is what GMTK names the newly created components.

content.raw:
For future reference:
DPMF = Dense Probability Mass Functions
MC = Mixture Component
MX = Mixture Index (Table)
content.html: For future reference: DPMF = Dense Probability Mass Functions MC = Mixture Component MX = Mixture Index (Table)

content.raw: According to the GMTK docs, DPMFs = dense probability mass functions
content.html: According to the GMTK docs, DPMFs = dense probability mass functions

content.raw: Thanks! Updated.
content.html: Thanks! Updated.

content.raw: When external feedback on the change in parameters is better understood, please post it in here. Specifically in the semisupervised case. Is semisuprvised seed unique to that specific testcase?
content.html: When external feedback on the change in parameters is better understood, please post it in here. Specifically in the semisupervised case. Is semisuprvised seed unique to that specific testcase?

content.raw: I may be wrong as I wasn't around for this, but the `simplesemisupervised` seed was specifically chosen because the seeds used for (eg, `simpleseg`) did not give coherent output in the `simplesemisupervised` test?
content.html: I may be wrong as I wasn't around for this, but the simplesemisupervised seed was specifically chosen because the seeds used for (eg, simpleseg) did not give coherent output in the simplesemisupervised test?

content.raw: Semisupervised seed was chosen to clearly create 4 labels (where simpleseg has effectively 3) and to explicitly label the result differently based on the region/label chosen.
content.html: Semisupervised seed was chosen to clearly create 4 labels (where simpleseg has effectively 3) and to explicitly label the result differently based on the region/label chosen.

content.raw: I'd put this comment right on top of the class definition to remove any possible ambiguity it might refer to the `type_name` only.
content.html: I'd put this comment right on top of the class definition to remove any possible ambiguity it might refer to the type_name only.

content.raw: Why was this removed?
content.html: Why was this removed?

content.raw: Accidental, will revert; some touchstones' params have regex in them and others don't and I probably accidentally overwrote this one thinking it didn't.
content.html: Accidental, will revert; some touchstones' params have regex in them and others don't and I probably accidentally overwrote this one thinking it didn't.

content.raw: Could you post the condition in GMTK this constant Dirichlet value change is supposed to address. The PR states it handles splitting/vanishing but it's not clear on how to reproduce the bug or what bug should be currently referenced. I realize this might be somewhere deep in the mailing list but it would be *very* useful to have it referenced here in case an issue like this crops up in the future.
content.html: Could you post the condition in GMTK this constant Dirichlet value change is supposed to address. The PR states it handles splitting/vanishing but it's not clear on how to reproduce the bug or what bug should be currently referenced. I realize this might be somewhere deep in the mailing list but it would be very useful to have it referenced here in case an issue like this crops up in the future.

content.raw:
We still don't have a test for reproducing splitting/vanishing, I came across the bug when running a comparatively large experiment with real data. The change from a uniform Dirichlet table to a Dirichlet constant is needed because the dimensions of the Dirichlet table must match the current component count for a mixture. If a component splits or vanishes in a mixture, it will not match anymore and there is no way to dynamically resize Dirichlet tables in GMTK. Since the table is uniform, it is mathematically equivalent to simply use a Dirichlet constant value instead (removing the need to resize anything as the same value will be applied to all available mixture components). Is that clearer?

The root bug that should be referenced is still the splitting/vanishing Gaussians bug ([ref](#!/hoffmanlab/segway/issues/113/accounting-for-gaussian-components)).
content.html:
We still don't have a test for reproducing splitting/vanishing, I came across the bug when running a comparatively large experiment with real data. The change from a uniform Dirichlet table to a Dirichlet constant is needed because the dimensions of the Dirichlet table must match the current component count for a mixture. If a component splits or vanishes in a mixture, it will not match anymore and there is no way to dynamically resize Dirichlet tables in GMTK. Since the table is uniform, it is mathematically equivalent to simply use a Dirichlet constant value instead (removing the need to resize anything as the same value will be applied to all available mixture components). Is that clearer?

The root bug that should be referenced is still the splitting/vanishing Gaussians bug (ref).

content.raw: Perfect. Thanks! References Issue #113
content.html: Perfect. Thanks! References Issue #113

content.raw: This used to be the Dirichlet table specification correct? And now `$dpmf_spec` refers to constant values instead of this table?
content.html: This used to be the Dirichlet table specification correct? And now $dpmf_spec refers to constant values instead of this table?

content.raw: Yes and yes, the dpmf table now uses a Dirichlet constant value instead of referencing the table that $dirichlet_spec would have defined
content.html: Yes and yes, the dpmf table now uses a Dirichlet constant value instead of referencing the table that $dirichlet_spec would have defined

content.raw: I'd add "(used by DPMFParamSpec)" just it's clear in future where/how it was replaced.
content.html: I'd add "(used by DPMFParamSpec)" just it's clear in future where/how it was replaced.

content.raw: I will add the comment, but I think the Dirichlet table can only be used by DPMF/SPMF tables anyways (and we don't have the latter).
content.html: I will add the comment, but I think the Dirichlet table can only be used by DPMF/SPMF tables anyways (and we don't have the latter).

content.raw: @hoffman this should be ready for your review.
content.html: @hoffman this should be ready for your review.

Currently the patch may fix the case where splitting/vanishing of Gaussians occurs even in the single mixture case. Previously, presumably the splitting/vanishing didn’t work correct before this patch even on a single mixture component since GMTK may decide to split if if deems it correct.

I’m not sure if this new fix is necessarily “correct” behavior in the single mixture case. At the very least it would seem this has the possibility of changing future Segway results from identical inputs and parameters since future runs may have Gaussians split even when the default number of components is 1.

@hoffman Is it worth while enforcing no splitting/vanishing for the default (one component) case by adjusting the mcvr and mcsr values? Maybe a major release number instead after this patch?

content.raw:
It turns out that the different resulting annotation for simplesemisupervised was due to splitting/vanishing Gaussians in the parameter evolution. Previously the extra means/variances were simply ignored. However, this patch enables the split/vanished Gaussians to now affect the parameter evolution which resulted in the different annotation. I chose a different seed for semisupervised which gives an annotation similar to the previous one:

Simplesemisupervised’s annotation before this patch: 

    chr1    0    1000    3    1000    .    0    1000    231,41,138 
    chr1    1000    2000    0    1000    .    1000    2000 27,158,119 
    chr1    2000    3000    1    1000    .    2000    3000    217,95,2 
    chr1    3000    4000    2    1000    .    3000    4000 117,112,179 
    chr1    4000    5000    3    1000    .    4000    5000 231,41,138 
    chr1    5000    6000    0    1000    .    5000    6000 27,158,119 
    chr1    6000    7000    1    1000    .    6000    7000    217,95,2 
    chr1    7000    8000    2    1000    .    7000    8000 117,112,179 

With the new seed and in this patch:

    chr1    0    1000    3    1000    .    0    1000    231,41,138 
    chr1    1000    2000    0    1000    .    1000    2000 27,158,119 
    chr1    2000    3000    2    1000    .    2000    3000 117,112,179 
    chr1    3000    4000    1    1000    .    3000    4000    217,95,2 
    chr1    4000    5000    3    1000    .    4000    5000 231,41,138 
    chr1    5000    6000    0    1000    .    5000    6000 27,158,119 
    chr1    6000    7000    2    1000    .    6000    7000 117,112,179 
    chr1    7000    8000    1    1000    .    7000    8000    217,95,2 

With supervised regions:

    chr1	0	1000	3
    chr1	4000	5000	3
content.html:
It turns out that the different resulting annotation for simplesemisupervised was due to splitting/vanishing Gaussians in the parameter evolution. Previously the extra means/variances were simply ignored. However, this patch enables the split/vanished Gaussians to now affect the parameter evolution which resulted in the different annotation. I chose a different seed for semisupervised which gives an annotation similar to the previous one:

Simplesemisupervised’s annotation before this patch: 

chr1    0    1000    3    1000    .    0    1000    231,41,138 
chr1    1000    2000    0    1000    .    1000    2000 27,158,119 
chr1    2000    3000    1    1000    .    2000    3000    217,95,2 
chr1    3000    4000    2    1000    .    3000    4000 117,112,179 
chr1    4000    5000    3    1000    .    4000    5000 231,41,138 
chr1    5000    6000    0    1000    .    5000    6000 27,158,119 
chr1    6000    7000    1    1000    .    6000    7000    217,95,2 
chr1    7000    8000    2    1000    .    7000    8000 117,112,179

With the new seed and in this patch:

chr1    0    1000    3    1000    .    0    1000    231,41,138 
chr1    1000    2000    0    1000    .    1000    2000 27,158,119 
chr1    2000    3000    2    1000    .    2000    3000 117,112,179 
chr1    3000    4000    1    1000    .    3000    4000    217,95,2 
chr1    4000    5000    3    1000    .    4000    5000 231,41,138 
chr1    5000    6000    0    1000    .    5000    6000 27,158,119 
chr1    6000    7000    2    1000    .    6000    7000 117,112,179 
chr1    7000    8000    1    1000    .    7000    8000    217,95,2

With supervised regions:

chr1    0   1000    3
chr1    4000    5000    3

content.raw: Would prefer for the cases where >1 mixture components is not used to not be changed. Mainly this is for potential speed reasons. An relatively easy way to implement this is with preprocessor macros, and having some code in the input.master that is only executed when number of mixture components >1.
content.html: Would prefer for the cases where >1 mixture components is not used to not be changed. Mainly this is for potential speed reasons. An relatively easy way to implement this is with preprocessor macros, and having some code in the input.master that is only executed when number of mixture components >1.

content.raw:
If I understand correctly, we effectively want to disable GMM when using 1 component. I think it is the presence of the MC/MX table which tells GMTK whether the model uses mixtures? In which case, do we just need to disable/ifndef those tables?   
 Alternatively, could we do this using using special MCVR/MSVR ratios set only for the single Gaussian case? It is an option provided to gmtkEMtrain \(p578 of GMTK’s 2014 manual\).

Do we want to give users the option to re-enable splitting/vanishing Gaussians with 1 mixture, somehow?

Also, should this be fixed in a separate PR? Single-component runs with split/vanish are going to error out right now \(without this patch\) anyways, and thus won't give the same result regardless of this patch. The goal of this patch was to allow for splitting/vanishing using Dirichlet constants instead of tables. If we include this issue in as well then this PR will have multiple major changes with multiple goals and I wasn’t sure if that was OK?
content.html:
If I understand correctly, we effectively want to disable GMM when using 1 component. I think it is the presence of the MC/MX table which tells GMTK whether the model uses mixtures? In which case, do we just need to disable/ifndef those tables?
Alternatively, could we do this using using special MCVR/MSVR ratios set only for the single Gaussian case? It is an option provided to gmtkEMtrain (p578 of GMTK’s 2014 manual).

Do we want to give users the option to re-enable splitting/vanishing Gaussians with 1 mixture, somehow?

Also, should this be fixed in a separate PR? Single-component runs with split/vanish are going to error out right now (without this patch) anyways, and thus won't give the same result regardless of this patch. The goal of this patch was to allow for splitting/vanishing using Dirichlet constants instead of tables. If we include this issue in as well then this PR will have multiple major changes with multiple goals and I wasn’t sure if that was OK?

content.raw:
I must be misremembering from a prior version of the GMTK object format. Looks like we always use MC/MX even in the one-component case? So never mind on the `#ifdef` stuff.

BTW you should delete any dead code rather than placing a `NOTE` comment above it. Version control means we can always get it back if we need it. Make sure you make a single commit to delete the code and make it clear in the commit description.
content.html:
I must be misremembering from a prior version of the GMTK object format. Looks like we always use MC/MX even in the one-component case? So never mind on the #ifdef stuff.

BTW you should delete any dead code rather than placing a NOTE comment above it. Version control means we can always get it back if we need it. Make sure you make a single commit to delete the code and make it clear in the commit description.

content.raw:
@hoffman this is ready for your review

I only have two comments for this PR.

1. Even though Segway already currently uses MC/MX even in the one-component case, this PR effectively fixes a bug where splitting and vanishing was happening in some specific cases even in the single mixture case. It seems they were erroneously being ignored. It still may be worthwhile considering an #ifdef set of code to enforce only a single Gaussian that may not split or vanish. Perhaps at least mentioned as a future enhancement? The only real concern here is that results after this PR may change even with identical input and seed if a split or vanish occurs and is no longer ignored.
2. The testcase parameters will need to be updated to reflect newer GLIBC versions after this PR is made.
content.html:
@hoffman this is ready for your review

I only have two comments for this PR.

  1. Even though Segway already currently uses MC/MX even in the one-component case, this PR effectively fixes a bug where splitting and vanishing was happening in some specific cases even in the single mixture case. It seems they were erroneously being ignored. It still may be worthwhile considering an #ifdef set of code to enforce only a single Gaussian that may not split or vanish. Perhaps at least mentioned as a future enhancement? The only real concern here is that results after this PR may change even with identical input and seed if a split or vanish occurs and is no longer ignored.
  2. The testcase parameters will need to be updated to reflect newer GLIBC versions after this PR is made.
